bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 25, 1890

div1.p: Lazear writes that he will be able to observe surgical operations in London. He discusses the theater, sightseeing, and a band concert.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 25, 1890

opener.dateline:
2 Queen's Square Place
London W. C.
July 25 1890

div1.p:
I wrote you a very
hurried unsatisfactory letter last Wednesday
morning. I was afraid it would not
get off in time. But I know now
that I had plenty of time, the mails
are put on board the boat at
Queenstown.

Monday night I reached London. On
Tuesday morning I found lodgings and
then went immediately to Barings
where I found a letter and papers
from you, I also got a letter this
morning. They were both full of news
and I enjoyed them very much. You
must take care of your stomach and
call in the doctor whenever you feel
badly.

Tuesday afternoon I simply wandered
around the streets and rode on the
omnibuses in order to get my bearings
and the general lay of the town
On Wednesday I trotted around a great
deal hunting up steamship offices.
I have engaged passage on the
Rotterdam sailing from A Amsterdam
on Sept. 6. I wanted to leave on
the Spaarndam on Sept. 13 but she
is full. However I left word that
if anyone should give up a berth on
the Spaarndam or a vacancy should
occur in any way, I wanted the
first chance at it. If I came by
the Rotterdam which is probable I
will reach New York on Sept. 18.
If I get a berth on the Spaarndam
I will reach there about the 24th.
Waring reached here on Wednesday
night and took a room in this
house. Norris will come down
next Monday. Waring goes to Paris
the first of next week and sails
from Boulogue on Aug. 9. Norris
has not yet completed his plans.

I have seen quite a number of the
sights here. I have been to St. Pauls.
Westminster Abbey, Kensington Museum,
Museum of Natural History besides seeing
all the chief streets and many of the
public buildings. Last night Waring and
I went to Covent Garden to the
Opera. They sang “Esmeralda” a new
opera by a young composer named
Thomas. It is really a very excellent
thing and there are some very fine
voices in the company which is French.
London just now seems to have a
craze for anything French.

Before leaving Edinburgh, I got four
of those pebble - brooches that you
spoke of. I got the prettiest that I
could find, but I do not think much
of them at the best.

I will send you a leaf or something
if I can find one. The grass does
not grow in the streets here by any
means. There is more noise and bustle
than in New York. They use omnibuses
and there is always a jam.

I picked some heather in bloom
on the side of Ben Lomond and
I will send it to you in this.

Sight seeing is not a very restful
exercise. I do not intend to rush
things, I think it is a bad practice.
It is better to see fewer things
and see them right.

I have not done anything about the
“Post”. I think it will be better to
have it sent to New York, as I will
not have a permanent address here.

Waring and I went to the British
Museum yesterday afternoon. Of course
we could not do justice to it in one
visit, but we got a general idea
of it and looked at some of the
things carefully. This morning we
went to Guy's and St. Thomas' Hospitals.
At St. Thomas' we saw several operations
by Sir William MacCoombe. They hold
operations there on Wednesday and
Saturday and at Guy's on Tuesday
and Friday. At half past one in each
place. I intend to go to them all
while I am here. Another large
hospital here is St. Bartholomew's.
I am going to hunt it up this
afternoon.

We tried to go to the Savoy last night
where the “Gondoliers” is still running but
it was full up so we went to a variety
theatre on Leicester Square called the
Empire. They had a very gorgeous
performance. I will try to get to the
Savoy again probably to-night. Drury Lane
theatre is closed, it will open soon
but hardly before I leave. There
are a great many other theatres open
with good plays and companies.

Daly's company is at the Lyceum
playing “As You Like It,” It has made
quite a hit here. Nat Goodwin an
American comedian is at the Gaiety.

The Hospitals I was at this morning are
on the other side of the Thames. We
crossed by London Bridge and came
back by Westminster Bridge. St. Thomas'
is on the Albert Embankment
immediately opposite the Houses
of Parliament. It is very large
and fine.
